newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL overnight falls on Bank Negara intervention.
newsitem.headline: KL overnight falls on Bank Negara intervention.

text.p: The overnight interbank rate opened at 8.5 percent before immediately slipping to 8.0 percent following an intervention by Bank Negara, dealers said on Friday.

They said the overnight rate was expected to ease further to around 7.5 percent against 5.90/6.00 on Thursday as liquidity pressure was mounting despite support from some principal dealers of the central bank.
They said the market was still liquid despite a central bank intervention in the morning to draw out one-month money for a second time this week.
"Now the big names are coming into the market to borrow, so rates are dropping," said a dealer with a local bank.

He said the central bank's principal dealers were supporting the overnight rate at a high level to give a psychological boost to interest rates after the central bank's two interventions this week failed to halt a decline in interest rates.
Dealers said Bank Negara had intervened in the morning to confirm it has raised its intervention level for one-month deposits to 7.05 percent from 6.95.
Short-term rates rose after the intervention, though it did not have much impact on longer-term rates, they said.
"It (Bank Negara) does not seem to have borrowed too much today. Otherwise the impact would have been seen in the rates," a dealer with a local bank said.
The dealers said one-week money was at 6.90/7.00 percent against 6.80/85, two-week at 7.00/10 against 6.85/90 and one-month money at 7.10 against 7.05/10.
Three-month money at 7.20/25 and six-month at 7.25/28, were both unchanged from Thursday.
Dealers said one-month money was threatening to fall below 7.05 percent in the morning, which prompted Bank Negara to intervene.
On Tuesday, Bank Negara Malaysia returned to the market after nearly three months to borrow for a one-month deposit at 6.95 to 7.05 percent against 6.95 previously.
Bank Negara regularly intervenes in the local interbank market to keep a check on liquidity or set interest rates as part of its efforts to fight inflation.
But it has not been in the market since May 24, despite rising liquidity that has pressured rates downward, threatening to thwart the Bank's tight monetary policy.
